{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3493779,"name":"RyanShoff","username":"RyanShoff","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/7c8e57/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-27T16:45:29.416Z","cooked":"

We’ve glued 971’s excellent Cuda Apriltag detector into Photonvision. We are testing it on the Nvidia Jetson Orin Nano Superduper Developer Kit. It’s working well enough to let other teams have at it. I’m sure it needs some cleanup before it can go into the main repo.

There are 3 github projects:
The photonvision fork and branch GitHub - FRC-Team-4143/photonvision at jetson-orin
The 971 library wrapped for photonvision GitHub - FRC-Team-4143/GpuDetectorJNI
A kernel driver for the Innovision ov9281 gs mipi camera GitHub - FRC-Team-4143/ov9281kernelmods: Innomaker ov9281 mipi camera Nvidia Jetson driver

The cuda apriltag library and camera driver have compiled binary releases. You don’t need the camera driver if using a usb camera. The Thrifty Bot ThiftyCam works great.

To test, install the cuda library in /usr/bin and clone the photonvision branch. Run ‘./gradlew buildAndCopyUI’ then ‘./gradlew run’. You should see a new ApriltagCuda pipeline. Refer to photonvision docs for complete build instructions.

Caveats: This will not work on your old Jetson nano. It only works on a newer Jetson Orin Nano. The camera driver is only for the Innovision ov9281 mipi cameras not other brands. You need to be running Jetpack 6.2. Also none of the controls on the ApriltagCuda tab do anything.

Our test bench has 2 CSI cameras at about 1280x720 resolution. We had about 55 fps per camera. @Coalman321 might be able to give more info on that since I was not very involved in testing.

hellllllllllllllllllllllll yeah; looking promising! Only notes so far are that at some point we should probably patch to support OPENCV8 unless just nulling out higher order terms is valid (which, it probably is?)

Once we have CI working, happy to move these repos into the photon github organization as well so we can put artifacts into our Maven server like we do for libcamera drivers.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-01-27T18:48:15.635Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":564,"readers_count":563,"score":247.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":483803,"topic_slug":"cuda-apriltag-detection-with-photonvision","display_username":"Matt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37738,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cuda-apriltag-detection-with-photonvision/483803/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3493900,"name":"Coalman321","username":"Coalman321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/b4bc9f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-27T19:01:54.655Z","cooked":"

Currently we use two OV9281 Monochrome cameras at their maximum resolution (1280 x 800). The images are pulled through our custom kernel module driver for these cameras on Jetpack 6.1/6.2. Without processing the image we can run at about 144 fps per camera. Our jetsons are configured to run in the new 25W (MAXN Super) mode, with the fan profile set to cool. Additionally we only use the Orin Nanos (same as the Orin Nano Super after a firmware upgrade), and not its bigger brother the Orin NX which also fits in the same carrier.

What we have found so far is that we are able to detect from two cameras simultaneously at 55 fps (55fps on camera 1 and 55fps on camera 2) consistently. Additionally, the latency is in the ballpark of 30 to 40ms with the GPU based detector accounting for about 15ms of that. Physical performance wise, the algorithm produces very similar measurements to the original CPU based implementation, while also matching or exceeding (in some cases) the maximum detection range. With both cameras running, it does use up most of the GPU bandwidth available, as it uses about 85-95% of available GPU time while running the pipelines.

Hopefully this answers your question

I’m trying to get a sense of where this compares with existing boards. I’m wondering if the hardware table here is up to date.

I know from experience the orange pi 5 can not keep 60 fps when processing multiple cameras. So, two cameras at 55 fps seems like it is better than anything that I know of.

Awesome. This certainly seems easier than using isaac_ros-apriltag…

Edit: Using two USB OV9281 cameras at 1280x800, it runs at around 36 FPS with ~26ms latency. The CPU apriltag pipeline runs at 18 FPS with 60ms latency, so this is quite the improvement.

mjbergman92:

I’m wondering if the hardware table here is up to date.

The last column in the spreadsheet has the software version used, which should give a rough date range.

While there’s no formal regression test to ensure same-hardware-new-software doesn’t significantly change processing performance, I’d expect the ‘scream test’ to fail if a commonly-used combo falls off in terms of performance from old to new software.

This is very, very good! For a $250 processor, it seems like this is doing the work of 3 Orange Pis. I might try and get my hands on one if they ever come back in stock…
Could this work on any computer with a Nvidia GPU?

Yeah, it does, I stripped out the 971 cuda library portion and made it take image input. I think I’m getting 3ms detection time on my 4060 mobile @ undecimated 1080p, if I instrumented things correctly. code’s here and pretty crude: GitHub - person4268/GpuDetectorJNI

Note that you will hit an assertion if you try and use decimate3.png (a 3840x2160 test image) because the detector has a limitation of pixel count being less than 1<<22, so use decimate2.png (the same image but 1920x1080).

@RyanShoff , I’m trying to replicate this using my Jetson Orin Nx 16G module sitting on a Seeed Studio J401 carrier board. The system has been flashed with JetPack 6.1 (L4T 36.4.0), installed OpenCV 4.11.0 with Cuda 12.6.

I’ve followed all the steps I can find from the photonvision fork and branch GitHub - FRC-Team-4143/photonvision at jetson-orin and
The 971 library wrapped for photonvision GitHub - FRC-Team-4143/GpuDetectorJNI . The only difference is that I’m using IMX219 CSI camera, which has default driver from Jetpack on Jetson SBC already.

I added these to QuirkyCamera.java:

                    // Add IMX219 for Jetson
                    new QuirkyCamera(
                            -1,  // USB VID (not applicable for CSI)
                            -1,  // USB PID (not applicable for CSI)
                            "vi-output, imx219 9-0010",  // Device path pattern
                            "IMX219 CSI Camera",  // Display name
                            CameraQuirk.Gain     // Add appropriate quirks
                    ));

According to Camera Matching document, it seems V4L connected cameras are assumed to be on USB bus not CSI, the CSI bus is always referring to libcamera library which is not supported by Jetson platform, thus it is only possible to use USB cameras on Jetson platform which is disappointing.

I wonder why V4L cannot be used for CSI cameras? V4L should support /dev/videoX the same standard way though.

I think I figured it out. Things are complicated. PV guys maintains a dedicated libcamera java package here: GitHub - PhotonVision/photon-libcamera-gl-driver: GPU-accelerated libcamera, which wraps C++ APIs of libcamera library as Java library to be load during startup or re-enumeration of cameras in the PV app.

to support Jetson CSI cameras, I need wrap libargus/gstreamer etc. C++ APIs as a Java package and release, then write a library loader in PV app to forceload it then call the wrapped C++ APIs.Quite some work but pretty straight-forward.

Any advice on how to debug this? Also, why does the error say USBFrameProvider when I’m reading thruogh CSI connector? Thanks in advance for any help you can provide.
